Hi,

2009/9/8 Aidan Morgan <aidos@...>:
>
> I would be most apprec=
iative if you could share your K-Means clustering
> code. I am currently in=
vestigating using K-Medoid Clustering (very similar
> to K-Means, but the c=
enter of a cluster is an existing value, not=A0a "created
> value" like in =
K-Means) for something else I am working on and am quite
> interested to se=
e how you went about creating a "sensible" K value :-).

FWIW I've uploaded=
 a 7zip file to:

http://sites.google.com/site/sharpneat/recent-builds

Als=
o on that google 'site' I'm writing an overview of speciation in
NEAT and w=
hy k-means may be a better choice. It's a work in progress
but some may be =
interested in reading it as it stands.

There's no magic really, I defined =
a class (CoordinateVector) that
represents a point in N-dimensional space. =
But unlike x,y coordinates
each element of the coordinate (the x and the y)=
 has an ID. Put
another way, each /dimension/ or axis has an ID. That way w=
e can have
coordinates that define a points in very high dimensional space
=
without having to allocate an element for every possible dimension.

My gen=
eric IGenome interface then has a Position property that gets a
CoordinateV=
ector object representing that genome's position. Initially
I just took the=
 innovation ID of each connection as the dimension/axis
ID (in CoordinateVe=
ctor) and the connection weight as the position on
that axis. I've just cha=
nged this slightly so that the transaltion
from genome to coordinate is per=
formed by a plugged in
'INeatCoordinateSystem'. More on that another time I=
 think.

My k-means algorithm (KMeansSpeciationStrategy) operates on a list=
 of
IGenomes by using their Position. Calculating centroids is a simple
ave=
rgaing of a list of CoordinateVectros and returns another
CoordinateVector =
object. One warning here, the centroid calculation
changes for different di=
stance metrics. For Euclidean distance we take
the mean, for Manhattan we t=
ake the median value - I'm attempting to
explain this as part of my speciat=
ion overview in the above URL.

It's also possible to run k-means without c=
entroids, by measuring the
average distance between a point and all points =
in a cluster rather
than betwene a point and the cluster centroid. Obviousl=
y this uses
more CPU time but I allow for teh possibility of 'centroid-less=
'
distance metrics in the code (I haven't fully thought through if this
is =
absolutely required yet).


k-mediods is an interesting suggestion. My init=
ial reaction (having
just read the wikipedia page) is that it's probably a =
good choice
compared to the original NEAT (O-NEAT) speciation but perhaps n=
ot
quite as good as k-means because the centroid is being artificially
limi=
ted to being one of the genomes - which is going to be a
sub-optimal choice=
 of centroid However, I suspect k-mediods and
k-means are both a big improv=
ment over O-NEAT and the gap between
k-mediods and k-means is minimal. Also=
 k-means isn't perfect, it forms
sub-optimal clusters (in terms of minimizi=
ng intra cluster variance)
so there may be yet better clustering algorithms=
 to consider.



> Could you also point me at the code in SharpNeat that do=
es the threshold
> adjustment dynamically for the regular Speciation?


Hav=
e a look at EvolutionAlgorith.AdjustSpeciationThreshold().

It started out =
as a fixed increment up or down and then I started
increasing the size of t=
he increment with each generation that we are
outside the target, sort of l=
ike an accelerating increment if you
like. It's far from perfect though, he=
nce the effort to improve
speciation.


Colin
